title-group.article-title: Effect of needle length, electrospinning distance, and solution concentration on morphological properties of polyamide-6 electrospun nanowebs

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Textile Engineering, Science and Research Branch, Islamic AZAD University, Iran
2Université de Haute Alsace, Laboratoire de Physique et Mécanique Textiles, France

author-notes.corresp: Amir Houshang Hekmati, Department of Textile Engineering, Science and Research Branch, Islamic AZAD University, Tehran, Iran. Email: Amir-houshang.hekmati@uha.fr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Nowadays, thanks to the electrospinning process, polymeric fibers in nanoscale diameters (10–500 nm) are easily producible. During the last decade, the electrospinning technique has been greatly investigated and developed. One of the most important fields of study on the electrospinning process is the influence of effective parameters on electrospun nanofibers and nanoweb properties. In this study, using polyamide-6 (PA-6)/formic acid polymer solution, three important parameters of the electrospinning process, including polymer solution concentration, needle-tip-to-collector distance, and needle length, were precisely studied. The solution concentration is a very important parameter that affects the nanowebs’ homogeneity and nanofibers’ diameter evenness. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis of the electrospun nanowebs showed that among five polymer solution concentrations (5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 wt%), 25 wt% was more suitable and provided the homogeneity and reproducibility of PA-6 nanowebs. It has been found that the needle-tip-to-collector distance had a considerable influence on the nanofibers’ diameter and the nanoweb collection zone. Morphological investigation and statistical studies showed that the nanofibers’ diameter increased with the reduction of the needle-tip-to-collector distance. Moreover, the average diameter of the nanoweb collection zone decreased by the reduction of this distance. The effect of needle length on the nanofibers’ morphology and nanowebs’ collection zone was investigated. Statistical analysis of the obtained results revealed that the increase of needle length significantly increased the average nanofibers’ diameter. Inversely, the diameter of the nanoweb collection zone reduced when needle length increased. All previously mentioned studies helped to define the optimal electrospinning condition to produce the bead-free, non-branched, and homogeneous PA-6 electrospun nanofibers and nanowebs.

body.p: Among the various ways to produce ultrafine fibers (such as drawing, template synthesis, phase separation, and self-assembly), electrospinning is the most interesting method for researchers.1 In the last decade the enthusiasm of working on nanofiber production via electrospinning and understanding the influence of different parameters of this process on nanofibers’ properties have been remarkably increased.

The electrospinning process, which has been known since 1934 by Formhals patents, forms the nanofibers through a positively charged polymer solution jet on a grounded metallic collector that can be static or rotating. A wide variety of polymers are electrospun by this method in two forms: polymer solution and polymer melt. The obtained electrospun nanowebs have different applications in different domains, such as medical uses,2–9 filtration industries,10–15 and protective clothes.16 Thanks to their unique morphological properties, such as high surface area to volume ratio, development of their application fields is of interest.17

The effect of feed rate, polymer concentration, voltage, the addition of salt, and plate size on the polycaprolactone (PCL) nanofiber diameter and length were investigated by Beachley and Wen.24 They did not find any significant effect of feed rate on the maximum fiber length, diameter, and uniformity of PCL nanofibers, whereas Megelski et al.25 observed that the nanofibers’ diameter increased by increasing the polymer feed rate. They also reported that the fiber length and diameter increased with increasing of polymer solution concentration and that the nanofibers’ diameter decreased by increasing the applied voltage.

Subbiah et al.26 collected some researches on process parameters and nanofiber morphology. The most important parameters that were presented in that review were solution concentration, applied voltage, nozzle collector distance, polymer flow rate, spinning environment, solution conductivity, and solvent evaporation.

This work is the first part of a series of studies to evaluate the possibility of using elastic nanowebs (nanomembranes) in micro-actuators. Due to the good elastic properties of polyamide-6 (PA-6), it was selected to be used for this study. The first step of this series of studies was optimization of the PA-6 electrospinning parameters to produce homogeneous and reproducible electrospun nanowebs. All parameters that affected the homogeneity and the reproducibility of the process were studied by using a LPMT (Laboratoire de Physique et Mécanique Textiles, Mulhouse, France) electrospinning machine. The polymer solution concentration, distance between the needle tip and collector, and needle length are three parameters that have been precisely studied in this work. Among these parameters the effect of needle properties is less reported in the literature. There are some studies on the form of the needle tip and its internal diameter, but there is no investigation concerning the effect of needle length on obtained electrospun nanowebs. The effects of needle-tip-to-collector distance and needle length on the electrospun nanowebs’ collection zone is another aspect in this work that has not been seriously investigated in other similar works. The obtained results of this study optimize the electrospinning process and ensure the homogeneity and reproducibility of PA-6 electrospun nanowebs.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Polyamide 6 (nylon-6) pellets Mw = 10,000 were obtained from Acros Organics, USA. Formic acid (90%) was purchased from Fisher Scientific, France. PA-6 polymer solution was prepared dissolving the PA-6 pellets in formic acid. Stirring was used for 12 hours (in ambient condition) to expedite dissolution.

sec.title: Electrospinning process
sec.p:
Polymer solution was electrospun in ambient pressure, humidity, and temperature. The electrospinning process was based on vertical projection. Figure 1 shows the LPMT electrospinning device. This device consists of different parts. An automatic pump feeds the polymer solution through the feeding tube. The polymer solution comes out from the spinning needle located above the collector. Between the needle and collector, a high-voltage electric field is applied by a high-voltage system that is placed beside the cabin. A system of automatic movement can move the collector vertically and the needle horizontally. This movement system helps us to change the needle situation during the electrospinning process. A security system was added to prevent any risk related to electricity; this system stops the applied voltage automatically when the cabin door is opened. The electrospinning device was insulated by a Plexiglas chamber and a Faraday cage to avoid electrical interference phenomena, and any disturbance of air flow. Figure 1.
Electrospinning device (Laboratoire de Physique et Mécanique Textiles (LPMT)): (1) automatic pump; (2) needle; (3) collector; (4) high-voltage system; (5) vertical moving system; (6) horizontal moving system.

To analyze the morphological properties of nanofibers and nanowebs in relation with electrospinning distance and needle properties, different electrospinning conditions have been selected and the process has been repeated 10 times for each condition. The constant and variable parameters of the different conditions are grouped in Table 1. Two types of needle (beveled and non-beveled) were used to study the effect of needle tip geometry on nanowebs’ collection zones. The samples D1, D2, D3, and D4 were electrospun by beveled needles and samples D1' , D2' , D3' , D4' , L1, L2, L3, and L4 were electrospun by non-beveled needles. Table 1.
The applied electrospinning parameters to study the effect of needle-tip-to-collector distance (beveled needle (D1–4) and non-beveled needle ( D1-4 ' )) and needle length (L1–4) on the nanofibers’ and nanowebs’ morphological properties
Beveled needles Non-beveled needles
Sample D1 D2 D3 D4
D1'
D2'
D3'
D4'
L1 L2 L3 L4
Electrospinning distance (cm) 20 15 10 5 20 15 10 5 20
Needle length (mm) 40 10 20 30 40
Needle diameter (mm) 0.7 0.8
Feed rate (ml/h) 0.353 0.119
Electrospinning time (min) 5 20
Applied voltage (kV) 30
Concentration (wt%) 25

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p: The electrospun samples were coated with gold and morphologically analyzed by SEM (Hitachi S-2360N).

sec.title: Atomic force microscopy
sec.p: The nanofibers’ surface morphologies were observed using atomic force microscopy (AFM; Nanoscope IIIa). Images were obtained by tapping the non-contact mode. Working in this mode avoids shear forces, which can damage soft samples and reduce image resolution.

The surface roughness value has been calculated by using the atomic force microscope’s software on the predefined surface parameters. The surface dimensions are 50 nm × 50 nm and the roughness (Ra) has been calculated by the average of 50 roughness values obtained from different parts of the nanofibers’ surfaces of each studied condition.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The statistical significance of the studied parameters (the effect of needle length and electrospinning distance on the nanofibers’ diameter and collection zone) has been analyzed by using the Student’s t-test and Tukey test.

sec.title: Effect of concentration
sec.p: Polymer solution concentration plays a key role in the electrospinning process. This parameter has an important influence on the physical and morphological properties of nanofibers obtained from different types of polymers.14,21,27,28 The effect of concentration on beading,21 branching,29 and the average diameter of nanofibers30 has been reported in the literature. In fact, there is a critical range of concentration that leads to produce bead-free and non-branched nanofibers. This range depends on the nature of the polymer solution (polymer and solvent properties). For example, it is possible to electrospin the 5 wt% concentration of polyacrylonitrile/N,N-dimethylformamide (PAN/DMF) polymer solution, but it is very difficult to produce electrospun nanofibers and nanowebs from PA-6/formic acid polymer solution with 5 wt% concentration. Moreover, the polymer properties also affect the electrospinnability. Two different molecular weights of a polymer do not provide the same electrospinnability.21,28,31

In order to obtain the optimum value of concentration and complete our previous study,32 different PA-6/formic acid solution concentrations (5, 15, 25 wt%) were electrospun, while the other electrospinning parameters were kept constant (applied voltage: 30 kV; distance: 20 cm; needle gauge: 0.7 mm in diameter; 30 mm in length; electrospinning time: 5 min; and number of replications: 10). The morphological properties of electrospun nanowebs have been investigated by SEM. Figure 2 shows the SEM micrographs of the PA-6 nanofibers that have been electrospun in the same processing conditions with three different concentrations. At a low polymer solution concentration (5 wt%), it was impossible to spin and just small polymer droplets have been generated (Figure 2(a)). For higher concentrations (15 wt%) electrospun nanofibers have been obtained, but the presence of branched nanofibers was observed and they were uneven in terms of diameter, so the produced nanowebs did not have the appropriate properties (Figure 2(b)). By increasing the concentration from 15 to 25 wt%, the branched nanofibers disappeared. Figure 2(c) shows electrospun nanowebs obtained from 25% concentration. This concentration provided bead-free, homogeneous, and non-branched nanofibers production. The differences of the nanofibers’ structure and diameter between the two concentrations can be linked to the differences in the rheological states of the polymer solution. Figure 2.
a) Scanning electron micrograph of polyamide-6 (PA-6) droplets obtained from 5 wt% solution concentration; (b) scanning electron micrograph of PA-6 electrospun nanowebs obtained from 15 wt% solution concentration; (c) scanning electron micrograph of PA-6 electrospun nanowebs obtained from 25 wt% solution concentration.

The obtained results show that the electrospinning largely depends on the polymer concentration and, more precisely, on the macromolecules’ arrangements into the solution. In a dilute state of solution concentration, there is no entanglement between chains, so it is impossible to produce nanofibers. The increase of polymer concentration makes it possible to electrospin nanofibers with different morphologies. The differences between two electrospun nanowebs (15 and 25 wt%) in terms of diameter regularity and homogeneity can be explained by a better stability of the Taylor cone during the electrospinning process. This stability can be due to a better cohesion between the polymer chains in the solution or to a stronger macromolecular arrangement. For a solution without entanglement among the polymer chains (inferior to 5%), it is impossible to obtain nanofibers.

The higher concentrations (larger than 25 wt%) were not studied due to the limitation of feeding pump. Therefore, among all studied concentrations 25 wt% is proposed as the optimal concentration. This concentration assures bead-free, non-branched, and homogeneous nanofibers production by using the LPMT electrospinning machine.

sec.title: Effect of needle-tip-to-collector distance
sec.p: The distance between the needle tip and collector is one of the most important parameters that have influence on the electrospinning process. According to the literature, the most common effect of this distance is on the solvent evaporation.14,33,34 To obtain defect-free electrospun nanofibers, a sufficient time of passage between the needle tip and collector is essential (it is needed for evaporation of solvent from the nanofibers). This time is determined by the needle-tip-to-collector distance. In order to study the effect of electrospinning distance on the electrospun nanofibers’ morphology, four different electrospinning conditions were considered (D1 = 20 cm, D2 = 15 cm, D3 = 10 cm, and D4 = 5 cm). All these conditions were varied only in needle-tip-to-collector distance; the other parameters were kept constant, as shown in Table 1.

All samples were electrospun in ambient temperature, humidity, and pressure. An aluminum foil was used as the collector and a beveled needle was used as the electrospinning capillary. The electrospinning process was repeated 10 times.

The first effect of decreasing the needle-tip-to-collector distance was observed exactly after the electrospinning process. The average diameter of nanowebs’ collection zones on the collector surface (the aluminum foil) was totally different. Figure 3(a)–(d) demonstrate the collection zone of electrospun nanowebs, respectively, for D1, D2, D3, and D4. As shown in these figures, the average diameter of the collection zone presents a considerable decrease by decreasing the needle-tip-to-collector distance. Moreover, the obtained shapes of the nanoweb collection zone for samples D1 and D2 were roughly circular, while for D3 and D4 the circular shape was changed. This could be caused by needle tip geometry because, in this study, metallic beveled needles were used as the electrospinning capillary. To investigate the effect of needle tip geometry, another study was performed using non-beveled needles, which will be described later. Figure 3.
Nanoweb collection zones for different needle-tip-to-collector distances by using beveled needles: (a) D1 = 20 cm; (b) D2 = 15 cm; (c) D3 = 10 cm; and (d) D4 = 5 cm.

The electrospun nanowebs’ morphologies were studied using a scanning electron microscope. The scanning electron micrographs demonstrated the regular surface morphology of nanowebs, which consisted of bead-free and non-branched nanofibers. The obtained micrographs were analyzed to investigate the effect of needle-tip-to-collector distance on the average diameter of nanofibers. The diameters of 150 individual nanofibers, which were randomly selected from 10 replications of the electrospinning process, were measured using Microstructure Measurement software and the average diameters of nanofibers and standard deviation were calculated. As shown in Figures 4 and 5, the average nanofibers’ diameters for 20 cm (D1), 15 cm (D2), 10 cm (D3), and 5 cm (D4) applied distances are 223 ± 8 nm, 277 ± 33 nm, 310 ± 43 nm, and 313 ± 76 nm, respectively. Figure 4.
Average diameter of nanofibers for different needle-tip-to-collector distances by using beveled needles: D1 = 20 cm; D2 = 15 cm; D3 = 10 cm; and D4 = 5 cm.
Figure 5.
Scanning electron micrographs of polyamide-6 (PA-6) electrospun nanowebs obtained from four diffrent needle-tip-to-collector distances by using beveled needles: (a) D1 (20 cm); (b) D2 (15 cm); (c) D3 (10 cm); and (d) D4 (5 cm).

The statistical analysis (Figure 6) shows that there is a significant increase in nanofiber diameter while the needle-tip-to-collector distance decreases from 20 to 10 cm. There is no significant effect of decreasing electrospinning distance from 10 to 5 cm on the nanofibers’ diameter. On the other hand, the decrease in needle-tip-to-collector distance leads to an increase in the polydispersity of nanofibers diameters. In fact, scanning electron micrographs (Figure 5) reveal that the reduction of the needle-tip-to-collector distance did not affect the solvent evaporation (the problem that was expected due to the literature reports33) and no difference was observed in the nanofibers’ morphology, except the average diameter of nanofibers. This means that even the distance of 5 cm is long enough for reaching the complete solvent evaporation. Figure 6.
The average diameter of nanofibers significantly increases while the needle-tip-to-collector distance decreases from 20 cm (D1) to 10 cm (D3). However, there is no significant effect of decreasing the electrospinning distance from 10 cm (D3) to 5 cm (D4) on the nanofibers’ diameter.

The increase in the nanofibers’ diameter can be explained by the shortness of bending and whipping time of the emitted solution jet from the needle tip in small distances between the needle tip and collector. The increase in the needle-tip-to-collector distance allows the polymer solution jet to bend and whip more (one of the main reasons for the diameter reduction of spun fiber in electrospinning34), so the nanofibers’ diameter will be decreased by the increase of this distance.

As mentioned before, the shape of the nanowebs’ collection zone for smaller electrospinning distances (D3 and D4) was not circular. This could be explained by needle tip geometry. To confirm this hypothesis, the same study was performed using non-beveled needles. All the experimental parameters, mentioned previously, were kept constant, but the electrospinning needles were replaced by non-beveled needles with the same gauge. Figure 7 shows the difference between beveled and non-beveled needles and their jet formations. Figure 7.
Polymer solution jet formation from (a) the beveled needle (b) the non-beveled needle.

Identically to the previous study, only the distance between the needle tip and collector was changed from 20 to 5 cm and the electrospinning conditions were the same as those presented in Table 1. The electrospinning process was repeated 10 times and samples were named D1' (20 cm), D2' (15 cm), D3' (10 cm), and D4' (5 cm). Figure 8(a)–(d) show the nanoweb collection zone for D1' , D2' , D3' , and D4' , respectively. Figure 8.
Nanoweb collection zones using non-beveled needles for different needle-to-collector distances: (a) D1' = 20 cm; (b) D2' = 15 cm; (c) D3' = 10 cm; and (d) D4' = 5 cm.

These photographs show that the reduction of the needle-tip-to-collector distance decreases the diameter of the nanoweb collection zone. In terms of the nanofibers’ diameter, the scanning electron micrographs (Figure 9) show the same results as the previous study. This means that the decrease in distance between the needle tip and collector causes an increase in the average diameters of the nanofibers. Thus, the effect of the needle-tip-to-collector distance on the nanoweb collection zone and the nanofibers’ diameter, again, was confirmed using a non-beveled needle. There was a difference in the shape of the nanowebs’ collection zone between beveled needles and non-beveled needles. As shown in Figure 3(c) and (d), the obtained nanowebs from the beveled needle did not have a circular collection zone, whereas using non-beveled electrospinning needle led to the production of nanowebs (Figure 8) with a completely circular collection zone for all applied distances ( D1' , D2' , D3' , and D4' ). Figure 9.
Scanning electron micrographs of polyamide-6 (PA-6) electrospun nanowebs obtained from four diffrent needle-to-collector distances by using non-beveled needles: (a) D1' (20 cm); (b) D2' (15 cm); (c) D3' (10 cm); and (d) D4' (5 cm).

As is evident in Figure 7, using a beveled needle (Figure 7(a)) makes the electrospinning jet inclined. In large distances (D1 = 20 cm and D2 = 15 cm), the inclination of the electrospinning jet does not affect the collection zone, because the distance between the needle tip and collector is large enough to make a circular nanoweb collection zone, but smaller distances (D3 = 10 cm and D4 = 5 cm) are not sufficient for the electrospinning jet to get its circular form and, so, the nanoweb collection zone becomes non-circular.

Contrary to beveled needles, by using a non-beveled needle, all obtained electrospun nanowebs had a circular collection zone. This is caused by the straight form of the electrospinning jet (Figure 7(b)). The distance between the needle tip and collector does not affect the electrospinning jet form and it keeps its natural straight form. Therefore, the nanowebs’ collection zone stays circular for all experimented distances between the needle tip and collector.

sec.title: Effect of needle length
sec.p: As described in the previous section, the shape of the needle tip has an important influence on the obtained electrospun nanowebs. In literature, there are some studies on needle tip geometry, its internal diameter, and its effect on the electrospun nanofibers’ morphological properties.23,35,36 The needle length is another aspect of the electrospinning capillary that can affect the electrospun nanofibers and nanowebs’ properties. Until now, the effect of needle length has not been precisely studied in the literature. The changes in polymer solution kinetic energy, which could be caused by changing the needle length, and their effects on the nanofibers’ morphological properties were the hypotheses of this part of our study.

To study the effect of needle length, four electrospinning conditions (L1, L2, L3, and L4) were considered. These electrospinning conditions varied only in needle length (Table 1)’ all other effective parameters (concentration, voltage, needle-tip-to-collector distance, internal diameter of needle, feed rate, and electrospinning time) were kept constant.
PA-6/formic acid solution (25 wt%) was prepared and the electrospinning process was replicated 10 times for each condition.

The comparison of obtained nanowebs from four different needle lengths demonstrated some morphological changes. The nanoweb collection zone was changed by the variation of needle length. Figure 10 shows the collection zones on aluminum foil for L1 (a), L2 (b), L3 (c), and L4 (d). Figure 10.
The effect of needle length on the nanowebs’ collection zone: (a) L1 = 10 mm; (b) L2 = 20 mm; (c) L3 = 30 mm; and (d) L4 = 40 mm.

The average diameter of the electrospun nanowebs’ collection zone was statistically analyzed. As shown in Figure 11, the Student’s t-test and Tukey test demonstrate that the average diameter of the collection zone decreases significantly by the increase of the electrospinning needle length. These averages for needle lengths of 10, 20, 30, and 40 were 12.6, 11, 10.2, and 9.4 cm, respectively. Figure 11.
The average diameter of the nanoweb collection zone decreases significantly with increasing electrospinning needle length.

To explain the observed effect of needle length on the nanoweb collection zone, it should be noted that the length of the needle affects the time of polymer solution passage through the needle. On the other hand, as shown in Figure 12, there is a considerable difference in diameter between the connecting part of needle with the feeding tube (d1) and the metallic part of the needle (d2). The diameter of d1 is five times larger than that of d2 and this difference affects the polymer solution flow and imposes the stress on polymer chains. Figure 12.
Difference in diameter between the connecting part (4 mm) and the main metallic part (0.8 mm) of the electrospinning needle.

The effect of needle length on the polymer solution kinetic energy could be presented as a hypothesis. The time of polymer solution passing through the needle increases with increasing needle length. So, it can be concluded that the kinetic energy of polymer solution will be decreased. The decrease in kinetic energy of polymer chains will decrease their whipping and bending during electrospinning. The reduction of polymer chains whipping and bending can increase the average nanofiber diameter and decrease the nanoweb collection zone. This hypothesis could be confirmed by results obtained from this study.

Figure 13(a) shows PA-6 electrospun nanowebs obtained from the L1 electrospinning condition (needle length 10 mm) and Figure 13(b) shows PA-6 electrospun nanowebs from the L2 electrospinning condition. These figures show that the electrospun nanowebs have a bead-free structure without branched fibers. Figure 13(c) and (d) show electrospun nanowebs obtained from L3 and L4 electrospinning conditions. The presence of branched nanofibers was observed in the obtained nanowebs from the L4 condition, whereas for three other conditions this effect has not been observed. So, using a needle with a length of 40 mm affects the homogeneity of electrospun nanofibers. Figure 13.
Scanning electron micrographs of polyamide-6 (PA-6) electrospun nanowebs obtained from four diffrent needle lengths: (a) L1 (10 mm); (b) L2 (20 mm); (c) L3 (30 mm); and (d) L4 (40 mm).

To calculate the average diameter of nanofibers for each length, the diameter of 150 individual nanofibers randomly selected from 10 replications of the electrospinning process were measured using Microstructure Measurement software. The obtained result is shown in Figure 14. The analysis of the scanning electron micrograph shows the averages of 155, 255, 271, and 286 nm for L1, L2, L3, and L4, respectively. The decrease in needle length significantly reduced the average diameter of the nanofibers (Figure 15). A remarkable decrease in the average diameter of nanofibers that were electrospun with the smallest needle length (10 mm) was observed. This phenomenon can be explained by high kinetic energy of polymer chains, which provides higher bending and whipping instability of the polymer solution jet during the electrospinning process. By increasing the needle length the relaxation time of polymer solution will increase, so the chains will be more relaxed from the stress that was occurred by changing the diameter between the connecting part of the needle and the metallic part. The differences in average diameters of nanofibers obtained from these four electrospinning condition (L1 L2, L3, and L4) shows the possibility of producing nanofibers with targeted diameters by changing the needle length. Figure 14.
Effect of needle length on the average diameter of polyamide-6 (PA-6) electrospun nanofibers.
Figure 15.
The decrease in needle length significantly reduced the average diameter of the nanofibers. A remarkable decrease in the average diameter of the nanofibers that were electrospun with the smallest needle length L1 (10 mm) is observed.

In order to characterize more precisely the morphological properties and surface topology of PA-6 nanowebs, which were electrospun using different needle lengths, the samples were studied using the AFM technique. The AFM analysis and images demonstrated that the electrospun nanowebs had a smooth surface (average roughness value (Ra): 9.7 nm).

Figure 16(a)–(d) are AFM photographs of the nanofibers’ surface, respectively, obtained from L1, L2, L3, and L4. The obtained values of roughness and their standard deviations (STDV) demonstrate that the needle length can affect the nanofibers’ surface topology. The average roughness values of the nanofibers’ surface decreases with the increase of needle length. Figure 16.
Atomic force microscopy images of polyamide-6 (PA-6) electrospun nanowebs obtained from four diffrent needle lengths: (a) L1 (10 mm); (b) L2 (20 mm); (c) L3 (30 mm); and (d) L4 (40 mm).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this work, three important parameters of the electrospinning process were studied. Polymer solution concentration was considered as a parameter that largely affected the electrospun nanowebs’ homogeneity and the nanofibers’ diameter evenness. Among studied polymer solution concentrations, 25 wt% provides a more homogeneous and reproducible electrospinning process.

The distance between the needle tip and collector is the second studied parameter. It was found that this parameter had an influence on the nanofibers’ diameter and the nanoweb collection zone. The reduction of the distance between the needle tip and collector decreases the nanoweb collection zone diameter. The statistical analysis shows that there is a significant increase in the average diameter of nanofibers when the needle-tip-to-collector distance decreases from 20 to 10 cm.

The needle properties (needle length and needle geometry) affect the morphology of nanofibers and nanowebs. The Student’s t-test and Tukey test demonstrate (Figure 15) that the average diameter of the collection zone decreases significantly with the increase of electrospinning needle length. The same tests show that the average diameter of nanofibers significantly increased with the increase of needle length. In terms of needle tip geometry, two different types of needle were used (beveled and non-beveled). Needle tip geometry affects the centralization of the nanoweb collection zone. A non-beveled needle makes it possible to produce a completely circular nanoweb collection zone over the collector surface.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
